content: We use AI for so much, for writing emails, summarizing reports, and even recommending what we eat. But behind all that magic, there is something called an AI model. If you ever wonder what models like GPD4, Claude, or Gymnite actually do, and how to choose the right one, this video is for you. And if you're thinking about building your own AI tools like smart assistant, a content generator, or a lead scoring app, I'll show you how platforms like Thrive actually do that without writing a single line of code. Let's dive in. An AM model is like a digital brain trains of ton of information. You ask it a question or give it a task and it gives you a response. That could be a piece of writing, a summary, an image, code, anything. But not all AI models are the same. Each one has different strengths, weaknesses, and ideal uses. Let's say you are building something with AI, like a customer support bot or a tool to organize your sales lead. Do you want it to answer fast, handle long documents, be great at writing? Different goals call for different models. Start by asking, what do I need this AI to do? Does it need to be fast, accurate, or cost effective? Am I working with private or sensitive data? Do I need deep reasoning or just a quick short answers? Once you're clear on what you need, choosing the right model becomes much easier. Let's take a look at some of the most widely used AI models today and what they are each designed to do. This will help you understand the range of capabilities out there and how different models are built with different goals in mind. GBD4 by OpenAI, a general purpose model built for deep reasoning, writing and complex tasks. Often used for research, coding, or anything that needs accuracy and context. Three, bionthropic. This is great for summarizing documents and maintaining a helpful balanced tone. Popular in customer support and document heavy use cases. Gemini 1.5 by Google. A multimodel model, meaning it can understand images, video, and text all at once. Used in tools that combine visual and written inputs. Mistral by Mistl AI. Open- source, lightweight, and designed for speed and efficiency. Often chosen for the smaller apps or when cost is a factor. Deepseek by DeepSci. Designed for technical tasks like math and code. It's a good fit for tools that requisi built for real-time responses using current web data. still evolving, but aim at use cases where up to the info is key. These are just a few examples of the most talked about models right now. Each one is optimized for different goals. So, understanding what you need is key before picking one. There's a big difference between just using AI and actually integrating it with into a tool or workflow. If you are building a software for your team or business, picking the right model is a big deal. Do you go with GBD4, HUD, Mistral? Which one is faster, safer, cheaper? That's where Glide comes in. Glide automatically selects the best model for your use case, whether it's summarizing text, classifying data, or generating content and connect you to the enterprisegrade version that's far secure and your data is never used for training. Once the model is set, you can build apps that put the AI power directly in your user's hands, whether it's internal teams or customers. Now, this means smarter inputs, a system workflows, or dynamic features, all inside your own custom software. No code required. So to recap, a models are the brains behind most modern tools. Each one has unique strengths. Pick based on what you need. And if you want to build with AI without being a developer, BL makes it possible. Did this help? Hit a like and subscribe for more videos about AI automation and building smart businesses. Got questions? Drop them in the comments. I'll read them all. I'll see you in the next one. title: What are AI Models? | AI Models Explained
author: Glide

key_facts: FACT: An AI model acts as a digital brain trained on vast amounts of information to generate responses to user queries.
FACT: AI models can produce text, summaries, images, code, and other content based on input tasks.
FACT: Different AI models have distinct strengths, weaknesses, and ideal use cases depending on the task.
FACT: Choosing an AI model depends on requirements such as speed, accuracy, cost, and data sensitivity.
FACT: GBD4 by OpenAI is optimized for deep reasoning, writing, and complex tasks like research and coding.
FACT: Three, bionthropic is designed for document summarization and maintaining a helpful, balanced tone in customer support.
FACT: Gemini 1.5 by Google is a multimodal model capable of processing text, images, and video simultaneously.
FACT: Mistral by Mistl AI is open-source, lightweight, and prioritizes speed and efficiency for smaller applications.
FACT: Deepseek by DeepSci specializes in technical tasks such as math and code generation with real-time web data access.
FACT: Glide is a platform that automatically selects the best AI model for a given use case without requiring code.
FACT: Glide connects users to enterprise-grade models with enhanced security and ensures data is never used for training.
FACT: AI models can be integrated into custom software to enable smart inputs, automated workflows, and dynamic features.
FACT: Building AI-powered tools without coding is possible using platforms like Glide.
key_opinions: OPINION: The choice of AI model significantly impacts performance, cost, and security in business applications.
OPINION: Open-source models like Mistral offer better control and transparency for developers and organizations.
OPINION: Real-time data access is critical for AI tools that require up-to-date information.
OPINION: Enterprise-grade AI integration should prioritize data privacy and compliance over raw model performance.
OPINION: Platforms like Glide democratize AI development by enabling non-developers to build intelligent tools.
OPINION: The future of AI lies not just in powerful models, but in seamless integration into everyday workflows.
key_datapoints: DATA: GBD4 by OpenAI is used for research, coding, and tasks requiring high accuracy and contextual understanding.
DATA: Three, bionthropic is popular in customer support and document-heavy environments due to its balanced tone.
DATA: Gemini 1.5 supports multimodal input including text, images, and video in a single processing pipeline.
DATA: Mistral is known for being lightweight and efficient, making it suitable for low-latency or budget-sensitive apps.
DATA: Deepseek excels in technical domains such as mathematical computation and code generation.
DATA: Glide provides enterprise-grade AI models with data privacy guarantees and no training data usage.
DATA: AI integration via platforms like Glide enables no-code development of internal tools and customer-facing apps.
